body.p: Le 7 janvier qui a vu naître V. A. R. est un jour trop intéressant pour moi pour que je puisse m'empêcher d'en parler à V. A. R.A letter to Henry from his brother Frederick II shows that the letter was carried by Count von Görtz, when the latter returned from delivering Frederick's congratulations on Paul's marriage to the new Grand Duchess Natalya Alekseevna (Politische Correspondenz Friedrich's des Großen, xxxv, p. 80 (Letter 22748)). The same letter from Frederick indicates that Görtz also brought the (false) news that the Pugachev Rebellion was not serious: Catherine does not mention the growing uprising in her letter to Henry. To avoid revealing this internal threat and potential weak point at a time when her first Russo-Turkish War was still raging and the negotiations concerning the first partition of Poland were not yet complete, she did not discuss the rebellion in her foreign correspondence at all at this time (see, for example, her letter to Voltaire sent the next day, on 7 January). Henry forwarded Catherine's letter to his brother on 10 February, writing: 'Je vous supplie de me dire ce que je dois répondre sur les deux articles les plus intéressants de sa lettre, le premier qui intéresse le roi de Suède, et le second qui me regarde à cause de l'invitation que l'Impératrice me fait pour la venir voir après la paix' ('I beg you to tell me how I should respond to the two most interesting points in her letter, the first involving the king of Sweden, and the second which concerns me due to the empress's invitation for me to come see her after peace is made'). Despite suffering from gout in his hands, Frederick responded quickly so that Henry could write back to Catherine immediately: he left Henry free to choose whether or not to visit Russia, noting that Catherine clearly very much wanted Henry to visit ('on voit qu'elle en a grande envie'). He instructed Henry to reassure Catherine boldly, since he knew that the French, who subsidised the Swedish crown, wanted to use Gustav to gain influence in Russia ('vous pourrez la rassurer hardiment, parceque, selon ce que j'en sais, les Français espèrent par lui gagner terrain en Russie'). (Politische Correspondenz Friedrich's des Großen, xxxv, p. 89 (Letter 22760).) By contrast, Frederick delayed answering the letter Catherine had sent to him on 4 January, alleging the same impediment of gout (Politische Correspondenz Friedrich's des Großen, xxxv, p. 90 (Letter 22762)). Henry, who had already visited Russia in Winter 1770/71, returned in 1776. Present at time of Grand Duchess Natalya Alekseevna's death in childbirth, Henry was then able to help arrange Paul's second marriage to the future Mariya Fedorovna. Gustav III of Sweden eventually visited St. Petersburg in June-July 1777. L'amitié sincère que Ses vertus m'ont inspirée ne peut que faire les vœux les plus vifs pour Sa précieuse conservation, pour Sa santé et Sa prospérité. Les hommes tels que Vous devraient non seulement vivre plusieurs siècles, pour servir par leurs qualités d'exemple au reste des humains, mais encore il leur faudrait un bonheur non interrompu pour encourager les hommes à les imiter. Il n'y a jusqu'à ma patronne, dont V. A. R. a eu la bonté de se souvenir encore cette année, que je n'invoque pour obtenir tout cela du ciel pour V. A. R.Henry regularly sent congratulations to Catherine on her birthday and nameday, beginning in 1771 after his first visit to Russia and ending when the Russo-Prussian alliance lapsed in 1780. The congratulatory letter mentioned here, presumably dating from the end of November 1773, does not appear to have survived, but Catherine acknowledged its receipt on 8 December 1773 ( Briefwechsel zwischen Heinrich Prinz von Preußen und Katharina II. von Rußland, p. 117). Mad. la landgrave qui, quoiqu'elle n'invoque point de saintes en Votre faveur, n'en aime pas moins V. A. R., ne m'a point laissée ignorer ses entretiens avec Elle.Upon her return from Russia in late 1773, Landgravine Karoline of Hesse-Darmstadt visited Berlin. In December, both Henry and Frederick politely mentioned in letters to Catherine their conversations with the landgravine about her trip to Russia for her daughter's wedding to the future Paul I ( Briefwechsel zwischen Heinrich Prinz von Preußen und Katharina II. von Rußland, pp. 116-17; Sbornik Imperatorskago Russkago Istoricheskago Obshchestva, xx (1877), pp. 334-35). J'étais en trop bonnes mains pour ne point baisser la tête avec résignation et me soumettre à vos arrêts. Cependant à propos de la jalousie du Baron de Schrautenbach envers Diderot, V. A. R. en a prononcé un contre ce dernier, dont, en honneur et en conscience, je suis obligée de le disculper, car il est de toute vérité que ce n'est pas lui que a écrit ni publié le système de la nature, que je n'ai jamais lu.In his letter to Catherine of 9 December 1773, Henry wrote: 'J'ai félicité le baron de Schrautenbach sur la conquête de madémoiselle Fimofski, il est jaloux de Diderot, il prétend que c'est lui qui veut le supplanter. [...] Je ne sais si l'auteur du système de la nature se laissa séduire par un amour bizarre, mais je sais bien qu'il a un jugement exquis, il le prouve en quittant Paris et la France pour aller voir gouverner une grande monarchie, pour connaître comment les peuples sont heureux, lorsqu'ils sont soumis par des lois sages, par des principes d'équité et justice' ( Briefwechsel zwischen Heinrich Prinz von Preußen und Katharina II. von Rußland, ed. by R. Krauel, Berlin: Alexander Duncker, 1903, pp. 116-17). Je suis persuadée que, si Diderot a le bonheur de voir V. A. R., il ne manquera pas de s'attirer Son approbation. C'est une tête comme on n'en rencontre guère sur son chemin; les choses les plus obscures, les plus difficiles deviennent aisées et claires entre ses mains. Outre cela il est impossible que la fertilité de son imagination n'amuse V. A. R., il est né poète, mais quoiqu'il fasse bien et facilement des vers, c'est le talent qu'il exercerce le moins. Ce qui n'échapperait point à V. A. R. et ce qui Lui plairait sans faute le plus, c'est l'extrême bonté et droiture d'âme de cet homme; c'est un cœur comme on voudrait que tous les hommes en eûssent. Je m'aperçois qu'en voulant le disculper j'ai fait son éloge, mais j'en appelle à V. A. R. et je suis persuadée que, si Elle le voit, Elle trouvera que je n'ai rien exagéré.Catherine similarly praises Diderot in two letters to Voltaire in January 1774 (D18762, D18782).

Le roi de Suède commence à parler pour la troisième fois de venir ici, je ne sais ce qui en arrivera. Lorsqu'il en parla pour la première, quinze jours après la révolution se fit, après la seconde proposition il tourna vers la Norvège.The 'révolution' is Gustav III's coup d'état of 8/19 August 1772: despite Russian-organised opposition, Gustav suspended the Swedish constitution, arrested leaders of the Swedish diet, acquired for himself greater powers, and thus reduced the opportunities for Russia to influence Swedish affairs via the diet. Taking advantage of Russia's ongoing war with the Ottoman Empire, Sweden mobilised its forces in autumn-winter 1772-1773 in hopes of acquiring new territories in Norway, but war in the Baltic was averted. Catherine mocked Gustav's promise to visit the following year in a letter to Henry of 22 August 1774 (Catherine II et Gustave III: une correspondance retrouvée, pp. 52-53; Briefwechsel zwischen Heinrich Prinz von Preußen und Katharina II. von Rußland, pp. 134-35). Gustav finally visited Russia in 1777. Nous voici à la troisième ouverture, faudra-t-il préparer des tentes ou des fêtes? alternative, rare dans le fait, mais que je n'ai pas voulu laisser ignorer à V. A. R. Aussi bien c'est Elle, je pense, qui en se rendant à mon invitation a mis à la mode me venir voir. Mais pourrais-je me flatter d'avoir ce plaisir une seconde fois après la paix? C'est une question qu'il dépend de V, A. R. de résoudre et de moi d'espérer de Son amitié, dès qu'Elle m'assurera qu'il n'y a point d'indiscrétion à la Lui faire.Henry visited Russia first in 1770-1771 and again, at Catherine and Grigory Potemkin's insistence, in 1776. His second visit was darkened by the death of Paul I's first wife, Natalya Alekseevna, whose mother, Landgravine Karoline, is mentioned in the present letter. Henry then helped to arrange Paul's second marriage to Sophie Dorothea of Württemberg, later Grand Duchess and then Empress Mariya Fedorovna.

closer.signed: En attendant toujours ne cesserai-je d'être avec la plus haute considération...

body.p: The 7th of January, which saw the birth of Your Royal Highness, is a day too dear to me for me to refrain from speaking of it to Your Royal Highness. The sincere friendship that Your virtues have inspired in me can only form the most ardent wishes for the preservation of Your precious life, for Your health and Your prosperity. Men like You should not only live for many centuries, so that their qualities might serve as an example to the rest of humanity, but also they would require uninterrupted happiness in order to encourage men to imitate them. L'amitié sincère que Ses vertus m'ont inspirée ne peut que faire les vœux les plus vifs pour Sa précieuse conservation, pour Sa santé et Sa prospérité. Les hommes tels que Vous devraient non seulement vivre plusieurs siècles, pour servir par leurs qualités d'exemple au reste des humains, mais encore il leur faudrait un bonheur non interrompu pour encourager les hommes à les imiter. I have invoked even my patron, whom Your Royal Highness was so kind as to remember again this year, to obtain all this from Heaven for Your Royal Highness. Although she invokes no saints in Your favour, the landgravine loves you know less and has not left me ignorant of her conversations with You. I was in too good of hands not to bow my head in resignation and submit myself to your judgments. However, as regards the Baron de Schrautenbach's jealousy towards Diderot, Your Royal Highness has pronounced one against the latter, whom, by my honour and in good conscience, I must exonerate. For he was not the one who wrote or published 'The System of Nature', which I have never read. I am convinced that, if Diderot has the happiness of seeing Your Royal Highness, he will not fail to win Your approval. His is the kind of head that one rarely finds in one's way; the most obscure and difficult things become easy and clear in his hands. Besides, his fertile imagination cannot fail to amuse Your Royal Highness: he was born a poet, but, although he composes verse well and easily, it is the talent that he exercises the least. Your Royal Highness will not fail to notice and will unfailingly be most pleased by the extreme goodness and rectitude of this man's soul; he has a heart such as one might wish all men had. I perceive that in seeking to exonerate him I have sung his praises, but I appeal to Your Royal Highness, and I am convinced that, if You see him, You will find that I have exaggerated nothing.

The king of Sweden has started to speak for the third time of coming here, and I do not know what will come of it. When he spoke of it for the first time, the revolution occured a fortnight later. After the second proposition, he took aim at Norway. Here we have the third overture: should we prepare tents or festivities? A rare alternative, in fact, but I did not want to leave Your Royal Highness ignorant of it. I also think that it was You, in yielding to my invitation, made it fashionable to come to see me. But may I flatter myself that I might have the pleasure a second time after the peace is made? It is a question that Your Royal Highness must resolve, and for which I must hope in Your friendship, as soon as You assure me that it is not indiscreet of me to ask it.

closer.signed: In the meantime I will never cease to be with the highest consideration...
